I agree with your claim that "Unpaid internships exploit college students," but partially due to your specific reason that interns are replacing employees.

In certain instances, companies may indeed use unpaid interns as a cheaper or even free labor alternative, which incentivizes the companies not to hire regular, paid employees. This can arguably be seen as exploitative because the interns are essentially doing the same work but without receiving monetary compensation, which is especially concerning if the internship does not provide substantial educational or experiential value.

Nevertheless, it's important to note that exploitation is contingent on the nature of the internship. If an unpaid internship is set up as a genuine educational program allowing students to gain valuable skills and experiences, then I would argue that it's not necessarily exploitative - though it may still be arguable based on different ethical standpoints. However, if the unpaid internship is essentially a replacement of regular employment without appropriate learning opportunities, then it indeed may be seen as exploitative. 

Therefore, your reason supports the claim, but only in instances where corporations are using internships to avoid hiring paid staff rather than providing a substantively educational program. For a comprehensive judgment, it would be important to evaluate each internship on its own merits and discern whether the benefits offered (educational or otherwise) can truly compensate the lack of pay.
